ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Harries is a brilliant lecturer and the content of the course is very interesting if you have a genuine interest in Descartes, but it is run like a lecture (not a seminar) and there are no opportunities for participation whatsoever.

Unfortunately, I think the class was a bit of a disappointment overall. Though this was technically a seminar, it was essebtially a lecture, as Professor Harries would comebto class every week with a typed lecture and proceed to read verbatim from the printed pages. This was incredibly unengaging and I struggled with this format the entire semester. There were few opportunities for discussion, and when people asked Professor Harries a question or he asked the class a question, the response was always relatively brief, from both parties. I think that the lecture-reading kind of suffocated the discussion spirit. His notes were extremely valuable and insightful, and it really was wonderful that he made them available on classes v2, but I don't think reading from them in class is the way to go. Rather than take the class, just read one of his books...
